A good opportunity to remember the work of Mādhava of Sangamagrāma (1340–1425) of the Kerala school of astronomy and mathematics in India. One of the greatest mathematician-astronomers of the Middle Ages, Madhava made pioneering contributions in calculus which included infinite series of trigonometric functions (centuries before any European, e.g., Gregory, Leibniz or Newton). In particular, this famously allowed precise and efficient computation of pi (now known as Madhava-Leibniz series). Madhava was remarkable in also providing correction terms of his infinite series formulations. To know more, his wiki page is a good place to start.

C = (d*3.3)*.95
C= (1*3.3)*.95 = 3.135
Pi=3.135
I can elaborate. We take the diameter and multiply it by 3.3 for the 33% curve of a perfect circle. But when you increase the length of a cylinder by 33% and it’s volume remains the same it has a 5% stretch or elastic potential energy. But the problem with a line is that it has a volume of 1 and it can’t stretch so it just loses 5% length. So c=(d*3.3)*.95
It’s just a lines length, it’s curve and it’s stretch. There’s only 3 factors.

Archimedes' approach to this problem was interesting, because at the time, many philosophers considered it to be impossible to measure the length of a curve. The reason for this is rather subtle, because they didn't have a problem with the idea of measuring the area of a curved region like a disk. This is because a bounded region must be greater in area than any inscribed shape and less in area than any circumsribed shape. Like, if I can draw a square entirely inside some curvy region and another square entirely outside it, then the curvy region must have an area between those two squares. But for arc lengths, that reasoning does not apply. Imagine drawing a very spiky star inside a circle. That star has a way larger perimeter than the circumference of the circle.

Archimedes reasoned--correctly--that the same containment ought to apply for convex regions. Today, there is no surviving ancient proof that the circumference and area of a circle depend only on their radius and radius squared, respectively. In other words, there is no surviving proof from the time that π is a constant independent of the circle. This fact cannot be proved from Euclid's axioms, because arc length cannot even be defined using those axioms except for piecewise-straight lines. Euclid's Elements presents Eudoxus of Cnidus's proof that A/r² is constant for all circles based on the axiom that "the whole is greater than the part," applied to areas, but he never once mentions a formula for the circumference of a circle. David Richeson speculates that Archimedes provided a proof that C = 2A/r (i.e. C = 2πr) in his work Measurement of a Circle, but that work only survives in fragmentary form, and such a theorem is absent.

However, the theorem can easily be proved from the two additional postulates Archimedes introduces in his work On the Sphere and the Cylinder which include measurements of the surface areas and volumes of spheres and cylinders. These two postulates are:
(1) A straight line has the least length of any curve connecting two given points, and
(2) If a curve concave in one direction connects two points and is entirely between another curve concave in the same direction connecting those points and a straight line connecting those points, then its length is strictly between the lengths of the other curve and the straight line.
Thus, we can sandwich a circle between regular polygons and determine its circumference the same way we determined its area. These postulates become theorems in modern geometry which use some sort of completeness axiom to prove the existence of limiting points necessary to do calculus.

Hello, I have thought about cirles and Pi and the connection between them for a while now and so this is my humble set of conclusions.... A circle is made up of straight lines between points on the circumference. It has no curves between points. None. 'Curves' then result from the placement of all these straight lines at an angle to the previous pair of points. Lots of them close together makes us see this overall effect. If there were very few points on the circumference then it would be more obvious that the circle is not actually made of curves. Why is this important? Well, it is important because we can now see what Pi is. The number of decimal places of Pi correlate to the number of points around the circle.... it's the granularity of precision of the calculation of the circumference we want. Note: Pi is (apparently) infinte which means we can describe a circle to the precision we want, ...... but we can NEVER get the most precision; i.e. there is no absolute solution of the equation Pi x diameter = circumference..... And this makes sense as well because we can always increase a chosen number of points around the circle  by simply adding more points in between them (by increasing the decimal place of Pi in the calculation). What is the conclusion then? 1) curves don't exist between points, 2) Pi is infinite, 3) the precision of the circumference of a circle is ONLY the result of the decimal places in Pi and 4) there is no 'complete' circle (no solution), just our misguided view that a circle has a contiguous circumference. This blows my mind, that we would never have enough time to calculate the absolute circumference of a circle and therefore the circumference can never be found from the diameter. They are just a conept that we can approximate towards.

Also the way they teach π is very confusing. Because Pi is the ratio of a square to a circle. When you compute the circumference of a square with a diameter of 1, you get 4.  
Or 1 x 4. Now the area of a square is length times width or diameter squared. Notice you don't use the radius. 

So to keep pi simple do it the exact same way. The circumference is 4 for a square of diameter of 1. So for a circle it is Pi or 3.14 for a diameter of 1. That is the constant ratio. (4 to 3.14). Square to circle.

3.14/4 = .785 the ratio of a square to a circle. Now the area for the circle is, the area of the square X .785. So for a square of 1 diameter, area = 1.. Circle of 1 diameter area = .785.

The whole point is keep it simple. A square and circle have a constant ratio. 4 to 3.14. So calculate the circle exactly like you would a square. No radius is used in calculating a square. Just the diameter.

Isaac Newton was in his early 20s when the Great Plague of London hit. He wasn’t a “Sir” yet, didn’t have that big formal wig. He was just another college student at Trinity College, Cambridge.
It would be another 200 years before scientists discovered the bacteria that causes plague, but even without knowing exactly why, folks back then still practiced some of the same things we do to avoid illness.
In 1665, it was a version of “social distancing” — a public health tool making a comeback this week as governments, schools and many businesses, including The Washington Post, send people home to try to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus.
Cambridge sent students home to continue their studies. For Newton, that meant Woolsthorpe Manor, the family estate about 60 miles northwest of Cambridge.
Without his professors to guide him, Newton apparently thrived. The year-plus he spent away was later referred to as his "annus mirabilis", the “year of wonders.”
First, he continued to work on mathematical problems (breaking Binomial Theorem which led to decimal value of Pi) he had begun at Cambridge; the papers he wrote on this became early calculus.
Next, he acquired a few prisms and experimented with them in his bedroom, even going so far as to bore a hole in his shutters so only a small beam could come through. From this sprung his theories on optics.
And right outside his window at Woolsthorpe, there was an apple tree. That apple tree.

"π" can described as series of product of trigonometric ratios. In this pattern, 3 is multiplied with a series of secant values of angles starting with 15 degrees that are divided by consecutive powers of 2. It goes like this: -

3 ×
(sec(15)) ×
(sec(15÷2)) ×
(sec(15÷4)) ×
(sec(15÷8)) ×
(sec(15÷16)) ×
(sec(15÷32)) ×
(sec(15÷64)) ×
(sec(15÷128)) × ...

Every new term introduced in the series brings the value closer and closer to "π", which is quite exciting!!!

Now that we understand how to calculate pi, what specific uses, in real life applications, does the number have?  And where would a need for the extended length of the infinite decimals of pi be used? Where would the thousandth or millionth decimal number (not decimal place) be necessary?

Not easy to put it into a text only reply, but lets try : My formula for calculating Pi :
Pi = Sum of  2^n * An * Bn ( that funny boxes simply mean Sum between 1 to infinity. ) . . . I divide the Circle, of any radius, but easiest with a radius of 1 into 4 right angled Triangles. . . So these 1st triangles have sides of 1, so A1 = 1, and B1 = 1. . . . n is just a number from 1 to infinity..

So the first line would be P = 2^1 * 1 * 1 . . . The remaining 4 curved segments then each divided into two more right angled triangles with sides A2 & B2. . . . And so you continue just dividing each remaining segment into ever smaller triangles, doubling the number each time. . . .

Then the 2nd line would be P = P + 2^2 * A2 * B2.. .
And so the 3rd Iteration would be P = P + 2^3 * A3 * B3.. . . You see how it goes. ? . . .
Very simple. . . .. . But since A1 = 1 and B1 = 1, then you have to work out what A2, A3, A4 etc and B2, B3, B4 etc will be. . . . .

So I found a way that just slots into a simple Iteration to do that. . . That is what I consider the clever part. . . . A2 = Sq.Rt ( ( A1^2 + B1^2 ) / 4 ) just repeat this for A3, A4 etc.
And B2 = 1 - Sq.Rt ( 1 - A2^2 ). . . So you see this is actually very simple, working out Sq.Rt's is the hardest part.

This formula is absolute for Pi, limited only by the accuracy of the computer you can use to do the calculations. . . . You can put these simple formula into a Spreadsheet, or you can put them into a BASIC program. . . This formula of mine, appears to work very much faster than others.

Basic Program ( n calculated slightly differently, easier for the computer)
10 PRINT “Calculating Pi” rem Program Title
20 P=0 : A=1 : B=1 : N=1 rem Initial Values
30 O=P : N=N*2 rem Start Loop
40 P=P+N*A*B rem Main Calculation
50 IF P=O THEN GOTO 80 rem Final Answer
60 C=(A*A+B*B)/4 : A=AQR(C) rem Next value for An
70 B=1-SQR(1-C) : GOTO 30 rem Next value for Bn
80 PRINT “ Pi = “ ; P rem Print Answer

Two comments:
1) Newton's method for evaluating Pi relies on the ability to easily and accurately evaluate square roots. Luckily, Newton also covered that part with the Newton-Raphson method. A complimentary video on the converging series a_n+1=0.5*(a_n+3/a_n) would be nice.
2) On the comment about five story buildings in NYC... AFAIK, the skyscrapers in midtown and downtown (and not in between) are there because the bedrock is closer to surface.

Great video, as usual. But the parting remark about skyscrapers in NYC is at least partially incorrect, as it's well documented that skyscrapers require very stable rock under their foundations and not all parts of the city have suitable rock close enough to the surface beneath them. The line of demarcation between lower buildings and skyscrapers is more likely determined by this rather than the construction technology available at the time the buildings were built. If this were not true, the land on which the lower buildings sit would've been purchased and the buildings razed to build skyscrapers to gain more capacity per acre of land.

Not to throw shade at Newton, but he was the beneficiary of several centuries of mathematical notation refinement.  For example, Newton did this work roughly around 1665.  Robert Recorde introduced algebra to England in the middle 1500's.  Mathematical relationships at that time were still using a mixture of words for symbols, such as cos - meaning "the thing" or what we would call the unknown, and the expression "is equal to".  Recorde is most remembered for not wanting to write "is equal to" any more somewhere around writing his third or fourth book and instead replaced the phrase with two parallel lines of equal length, as in =.  Imagine how slowly mathematical progress would have been without these incremental improvements.  It would appear critical mass was achieved in the 17'th century.

References to Pi in Aryabhatiya
The Aryabhatiya, written in Sanskrit consists of 108 verses divided into 4 padas or chapters. The second pada called the Ganitapada (Ganita = mathematics) bears a reference to the concept (and approximate value) of pi. In Ganitapada 10, Aryabhata says
“caturadhikam śatamaṣṭaguṇam dvāṣaṣṭistathā sahasrāṇām
ayutadvayaviṣkambhasyāsanno vṛttapariṇāhaḥ”
(Please note the format of this verse. It is extremely similar to the Vedic Mathematics sutras popularized by Shri. Bharati Tirtha Maharaj and refers to a form of writing in the Vedic times that was intended to be easy to memorize and thus recall).
Translated into English, this verse means: “Add four to 100, multiply by eight, and then add 62,000. By this rule the circumference of a circle with a diameter of 20,000 can be approached.
In other words, what Aryabhata said was that circumference of a circle with a diameter of 20000 is (4+100) x8 +62000= 62832. And we know that the value of pi is the ratio of the circumference to the diameter, so in this case 62832/20000, which is incredibly 3.1416.

My Formula for calculating the value of  Pi, works by dividing across a Circle with a radius of 1, into  4 right-angled Triangles.   The lengths of the Triangle right-angled sides, A1 and B1 are obviously 1 the radius.     Add the area of these four triangles together.     This now leaves  4 curved segments, outside the triangles.    Now divide these segments in to two equal halves, with a short 90° line.    This short line is B2  the long base of each of those two triangles is A2.    Now you calculate the area of these 8 small triangles, and add them to the sum total.     These small triangles each leave even smaller curved segments.    So now you divide these smaller triangles into 16 smaller triangles.    Then continue this process to infinity or as far as your computer can handle the numbers.       My formula   2^n x An x Bn      See the calculations for An and Bn below. . .   This formula home in very much faster than other formula I have seen.

PI ! 1: tracer un cercle de 100 mm de diamètre!
2: noter les 4 points 0, 90, 180, 270, 360 degré ,ce dernier qui rejoint le 0!
3: tracer une ligne du point 270 à 90 qui se trouve être le diamètre!
4: tracer une ligne du point 0,360 et le centre du cercle!
5: tracer une ligne du point 0,360 au point 90 et une ligne du point 0,360 a 270, vous obtenez deux triangles, celui de droite triangle 1, celui de gauche triangle 2
6: calculer l'hypoténuse du triangle 1! racine carré de 50² + 50² = 70.71067812!
7: diviser par 2 = 35.35533906 le milieu ou la moitié de cette ligne
8: tracer une ligne de cette moitié de l’hypoténuse triangle 1 au point 270, Vous créez un 3eme triangle,cette ligne est l'hypoténuse du triangle 3 et représente le quart du cercle!
9: pour calculer l'hypoténuse du triangle 3! racine carré de l'hypoténuse au carré du triangle 1 + la moitié de l'hypoténuse au carré du triangle 1 , racine carré de 70.71067812 ² + 35.35533906 ² = 79.05694151 Le quart de cercle 79.05694151 !
10: rapport quart de cercle : diamètre divisé par l'hypoténuse du triangle 3 ! 100/79.05694151= 1.264911064 ce nombre en utilisant la méthode précédente de calcul quelle que soit le diamètre reste inchangé, pour obtenir le quart de cercle 100/1.264911064= 79.05694151 ou 79.05694151*1.264911064=100
Un quart de cercle de 90mm*1.264911064=113.8419958 diamètre du cercle 360 mm !
1.264911064 est le rapport du diamètre et du quart de cercle et afin d'établir le rapport circonférence et diamètre nommé PI , ce rapport doit être élevé au carré pour faciliter la conversion ainsi que le quart de cercle ensuite transformer chaque résultat d'opération en fraction ! 1.264911064²= 1.6 , 1 * 4 = 4² = 16
fraction au carré, comprendre qu' 1.6 et 16 sont des valeurs élevé au carré, les fractions sont au carré, qu'il faudra réduire ensuite : l'ensemble de l'opération doit être ramené à sa racine : 1.6 = 8|5, 16= 16|1 , 16|1 / 8|5 = 10|1 = racine carré de 10 = 3.16227766!
circonférence divisée par la racine carré de 10 est égale au diamètre! diamètre divisée par (la racine carré de 1.6) ou 1.264911064 est égale au quart de cercle! 360 / racine carré de 10= 113.8419958 / 1.264911064=90 pour retrouver le quart de cercle !
pour un cercle de 360/ par la racine carré de 10= 113.8419958/2=56.92099788 le rayon !
racine carré de 56.92099788²+56.92099788²=80.498447719 hypoténuse triangle 1
80.498447719/2=40.24922359 la moitié de l'hypoténuse 1
hypoténuse triangle 3: racine carré de 80.498447719²+40.24922359²= le quart de cercle la racine carré de 10 s'impose par elle même selon que l'on utilise 1.264911064 qui est une valeur fixe commune à tout diamètre et 4 fois le quart de cercle comme par exemple : 360 mm / (racine carré de 4²/1.264911064²) ou (4/1.264911064) = 113.8419958 !
Avec un diamètre de 1 mm : (racine carré de 0.5² + 0.5²) = 0,70710678118654752440084436210485 divisé par 2 pour obtenir Hypoténuse3 = 0,707106781118/2 = 0,353553390593
hypoténuse 3 = (racine carré de 0,70710678118² + 0,353553390593²) = 0,790569415042
Diamètre divisé par hypoténuse 3 : 1/0,790569415042= 1,2649110640673517327995574177731 !
Reprendre le diamètre de 100 et considérer toujours PI comme la racine carré de 10 , 100 * 3,1622776601= 316.2277660168 ! hypoténuse 3 ( 0.790569415042) * 4 donne toujours 3.162277660168 !
Reprendre le diamètre de 1 multipliée par la racine carré de 10 , donne 3.1622776601 !
d'utiliser la formule ( 4/1.264911064 ) à l'inverse avec le diamètre de 100 et avec 3.14 , le résultat donne 314.1592654/4= 78.53981634 * 1.264911064= 99.34588265 , le diamètre de 100 n'apparait plus!
Utiliser de la même manière avec le diamètre de 1 et 3.14 , le diamètre de 1 n'apparait pas et le résultat est inférieur puisqu'il donne 0.9934588265 ! 4 ne dépend pas du diamètre , ce chiffre est le multiplicateur du quart de cercle pour obtenir les quatre quarts qui forme le cercle , 1.264911064 dépend d'un diamètre et d'un quart de cercle, avec ces deux valeurs , 3.14 ne permet pas de retrouver le diamètre initiale ! utilisation d'un diamètre différent de 1 et de 10 ! 120* (racine carré de 10)= 379.4733192 de la même manière quelque soit le diamètre, 1.264911064 réapparait ! et 120* (racine carré de 9,86960440108935) qui est égale à 3.14159265 = 376.9911184 avec PI 3.14 , le diamètre de 120 ne réapparait pas en utilisant toutes les méthodes proposées ! hyp3 , de diamètre 100 ! 0.790569415042 * 4 donne toujours 3.162277660168 sans utiliser PI ! il manque le calcul de 100 ! 100*(4/1.264911064)=316.22776601 ! 4\1.264911064=3.1622776 racine carré de 10 ! 360 mm divisé par ( 4/1.264911064) , 4 pour extraire le quart de cercle qui est de valeur connue 90 et le rapport ( quart de cercle x , diamètre x ) = 113.8419958 ! 360 divisé par 4 , donne 90 , 1 quart de cercle de 360 mm , le résultat de 113.8419958 divisé par 1.264911064 donne comme résultat, 90 , l'hyp 3 ! à l'intérieur du rapport (quart de cercle, diamètre) qui est égale à 1.264911064 , se trouve 1 quart de cercle x , un diamètre x ! pour extraire le diamètre x , il suffit de donner une valeur au quart de cercle x multiplié par le rapport , pour extraire le quart de cercle x , il suffit de donner une valeur au diamètre x ,divisé par le rapport en l’occurrence 1.264911064 ! 3.14 est faux , 3.16 est juste !

The first upper-bound given in the video, 3 < π < 4, can easily be improved by scaling up the hexagon (which gives the lower bound 3) with a factor 1 / (1/2 * √3) = 2/3 * √3. There 1/2 * √3 is the height of each triangle in the hexagon scaling it up by 2/3 * √3 will place the circle inside this scaled up hexagon. This scaled up hexagon has perimeter 6 * 2/3 * √3 = 4√3 therefore 2π < 4√3 so π < 2√3 = 3.4641016151377544.

As it goes the end of the video, the buildings becoming taller as technology advances, I have the theory that isolated civilizations built pyramids to celebrate the discovery of the Pythagorean Theorem. If you bisect a pyramid vertically, you get the right triangle. the pyramid thus, is the simplest possible geometrical solid composed of triangle and square. It is the 3d version of the right triangle, its right angle comes from the square, and sharp angle comes from the triangle. So, civilizations that achieved this knowledge were able to construct buildings and temples and had an enormous technological advantage over those who did not. Western civilization benefited from Egypt through the greeks and arabs who did not had to discover this by themselves. Its the only explanation why remote and far gone civilizations built pyramids.

2^62 is not divisible by 6.  So wondering how he was bisecting the circle . He had to start with square and not hexagon . Which doesn't make much sense , why would you start with square instead of hexagon ? Secondly ,sad fact  : when we talk about  Pi, those results by fundamental formulas as C=2Pi*r  , A=Pi*r^2  have never been proven . Newton just made everything more effective . But all can be still traced back to bisecting a circle and using pytaghoras theorem. The fundamental problem of this method is the bisecting itself . This has a lot to do with Zeno paradox of dividing by 2.  But instead of doubling the problem by every bisection the problem multiply by 6.  So in case of 2^62 polygon , you have exact same  amount of problems ,where the line is shorter than the curve above the line . This method we use has this fundamental flaw and logically we never ever can reach the end .  The definition of PI  , Pi=c/d  is correct ,the problem is we don't have and never will have the "c" . The "c" is approximation by polygon ,it is not the circumference.

This is how PIZZA get it's name:
Unknown circular disk shaped food item of thickness " a " and of radius "z"
The volume of the item will be
Volume= π × (radius)^2 × thickness
= π × z^2 × a
= pi × zz × a
= pizza 🍕

1:33 Easiest way to illustrate π to kids:
1. Inscribe a circle within a square
2. Divide square into 4 quadrants
3. Circle < square
4. Circle < 4

I find getting to the π>3 part is harder for them to wrap their head around, and it's easier just inscribing a cross in a quadrant and seeing how the circle makes up >½ the outermost triangles.

There was an intuitive jump at the beginning of the video which may need explaining to some.  First, the circumference of a circle divided by its diameter (or 2 times it's radius) is  pi.  Then you jumped from diameter to radius (r) as a unit of measurement.  So the circumference of a circle is 2r times pi.  Since the length of the rectangle in the rearranged pizza is 1/2 the circumference, the length is 1/2 * 2r * pi, or r * pi, or pi * r.  And the area of a "unit circle" is the area of a circle with a radius of 1, or pi.

It's easier to see if you put a set square of 360 degrees on a picture of old TVs test pattern for example. 360degrees being 1 circle

You can calculate anything that way with degrees. You can calculate "nothing" precisely in the process, too as the outside of the circle. The TV and computer invention uses the same pattern and algorithm 4:4:4 of 1234 infinitely.

Using both properly is an algorithm to multiply divisions or divide multiplications infinitely.

The Greek alphabet letters are ways to calculate that way for specific functions, as well.

I'm not a mathematician. But what if math tells us? This video gave me an idea. We see the world in three dimensions. But it's not a secret for anyone that we live in a four-dimensional world. With the help of mathematics, we can count several dimensions ahead. It's complicated. What if attempts to predict the laws of higher dimensions are doomed to failure due to one mistake? The same as in the Pascal pyramid. The same as in determining the number of PI. What if our alternate dimensions were calculated as Newton thought? This affects the macro and micro world. When we try to find an infinitely larger number, it turns out to be infinitely small. Perhaps calculating fractional measurements should give us a hint? I feel that I have found a certain pattern, but I cannot fully express it. I am from Russia, and our language is very capacious. It is difficult to express the full range of emotions. But intuitively, I think I get it.
All calculations related to odd and even numbers lead us to the 4-2-1 loop. What if there are no higher dimensions? Perhaps there are other many dimensions outside of prime numbers that are in the fractional space described in Pascal's pyramid? Like a beam of light passing through a glass prism. When one gets an infinite variety of different options.

I actually had an idea with the bisection method which might be interesting.  Instead of making polygons on the inside and outside, what if you made one that had a perimeter of 2pi, and saw where it intersected with a circle.  Doing so I found that it actually very quickly approaches interesting the circle at the same percentage distance between each vertex and midpoint.  It even seemed to be a fairly simple number, I think like 5^(-1/2) or something.  It’s been a while since I worked it out.  Using this you then just started over, this time making the distance to this point between the midpoint and the vertex equal to 1.  You find that as the number of sides increases, the perimeter of the shape very quickly approaches pi.

Really appreciate the work of the great Mathematicians worked for pie.

But there is one more Mathematician, whose research work is forgotten. It was Aryabhatta (476AD–550AD), a great Indian Mathematician and Physicist, who gave the correct value of Pi upto 4 decimal places as 3.1416. Not just that, he also stated that this value is approximate and not accurate which means he probably knew the irrational nature of Pi.

Below is the verse from one of the Mathematics book written by him "Aryabhatiyam", written in Sanskrit Language, where he states the calculation of the value of Pi.


Lines from his book 'Aryabhatiyam':

चतुरधिकम् शतम्, अष्टगुणम् द्वाषष्टि
तथा सहस्राणाम् अयुत द्वय विष्कम्भस्य
आसन्न: वृत्त


Translation (word by word):

चतुरधिकम् शतम् =(4 more than 100)= 100+4 = 104;
अष्टगुणम् =(then multiplied by 8)= 104 * 8 = 832;
द्वाषष्टि = 62; तथा = thus; सहस्राणाम् =(thousand times)= 62 * 1000 = 62,000;
अयुत = ten thousand fold;द्वय = by two (so अयुत द्वय = divide by (10,000 * 2 = 20,000))
विष्कम्भस्य = of the diameter of a circle; आसन्न: = approximately; वृत्त = circle; परिणाह: = circumference


Final Calculation:

(((100+4) * 8 + (62 * 1000)) / 20000) * Diameter = Circumfrence of a circle, approximately.

(62,832 / 20,000) * Diameter = Circumfrence of a circle, approximately
or
3.1416 * D = Circumfrence of a circle, approximately.

Of course pi was going to be irrational. If a point is first, a line second, a triangle third, a square 4th, a pentagon 5th, then the shape with sides so small they don't exist ( ie infinite ) is a circle. Here is a simple Pi calculation based on what I learned in this video... where S is the number of Sides of the polygon drawn inside the circle:
Pi = sin(360/S/2) * S
For S = 1 Trillion, I got this number which matches Pi to 23 digits: 3.1415926535897932384626382155667
NOTES:
1.) Make sure your calculator is set to degrees (not radians, etc) when using sin, or you'll get bad results.
2.) Windows calculator works fine in 'scientific' mode.
3.) Yes -- this formula will always yield a number smaller than Pi, but very accurate when S is large.
4.) Formula based on the fact that an S-sided polygon will contain 2S right triangles, so we can use sin to calc the base. The needful angle for sin input is 360 / S / 2. The base is in turn multiplied by S to get the perimeter of the polygon.... which approximates the circumference of our circle... enjoy!
EDIT: addendum
5.) I'm not saying I'm the 1st to find this formula -- surely someone thought of using sine or cosine to calc Pi before, right? Don't know either way, really.
6.) Please try the formula and let the results be your proof or disproof of its efficacy... thanks!

The most amazing thing about our species, is how we share information with each other so seamlessly. New technology is of course sold, but any new scientific discovery is just shared, free of charge and that lets us barge forwards in rapid speed. This particular trait, along with our much higher social needs, are thought as the reasons why we,  Homo Sapiens, ended up as the masters of the planet. We evolved a set of abilities that would allow us to survive in our natural environment, but by pure chance, the very same traits allowed us to ascend from our natural environment and adapt to anywhere, while still growing and discovering new tools that further enhance our already OP abilities. This video is also an excellent example of just that. I have never fully understood equations, but I've simultaneously always had an easy time understanding geometry, no matter how advanced. This videos mention of pascals triangle gave me an epiphany and I now see how easily convertible that some equations are and I suspect it is very much the same with a lot of other equations. I seem to find more and more that it isn't because I can't understand equations (as my primary school math teacher used to say), but rather that I don't really get the trick in the tools taught by the school system. However, these older tools seem simpler and as it's mathematics, thus better.

Overall nice video, just one criticism, when you did the series of 1/(1+x), you gave the impression that the series would work for all x. It doesn't, when you extend the binomial theorem to from non negative integers, the series you get would never work for abs(x) > 1, and would occasionally for abs(x) = 1, for example if you plug for the series of 1/(1+x), x=-2, the series would diverge for infinity, and if you plug x= 1, you would get 1-1+1-1+1.... = 1/2.

His explanation of building height in New York City is wrong. High rise buildings must have their foundations embedded in bedrock. Beneath the ground in New York City is a vast underground mountain chain that undulates, so it is near the surface in some areas and buried very deep in others. The high rise buildings are built over the areas where the bedrock is close enough to the surface so the foundations can be embedded in it. Areas where the bedrock is too deep to be used, have buildings that are much shorter. It has absolutely nothing to do with technological advancements.

Mathematicians are obsessive compulsive.  All I did was measure out a circle with a diameter of 10 feet across to an accuracy of .001".  That is easy to do.  Then I took a .010" thick wire and ran it around the circle.  Then I measured the length of the wire.  That gave me Pi to 3.1416.  Also the fraction of 22/7 = 3.1428571 is a pretty good approximation which is only 0.04025% bigger than Pi and makes Pi equal to 3.14151926518.  This is Pi to more than 10 digits of accuracy.  What engineering problem out there requires Pi to a higher accuracy than that?  None.  More digits than around 10 becomes meaningless in the real world.

The difference in perimeters of the square outside the unit circle and a square inside the circle is 1.1715728752538099023966225515806. The median of that number which represents the circumference of the unit circle is 0.8584073464102067615373566167205 (less than the outer square circumference (divided by 2)). If you subtract that figure from 1 you get the decimal places of pi. Is this an example of circular reasoning?

The ratio of the difference in the circumferences of the squares applied to the magnitude of the difference and subtracted from the difference and added to the inner circle, gets a result of 6, the circumference of the hexagon or the circumference of a circle with radius 0.95492965855137201461330258023509. @Veritasium (or anyone else), here's a funny/interesting little thing about numbers and infinity.
ok, so there are "uncountably" many numbers
we can split those into rational numbers, and irrational number.

rational numbers are an integer divided by an integer, so, they are countably many, that means, the irrational numbers, are what makes the real numbers, uncountable.

now irrational numbers are like, pi, square root of 2, and so on.

every irrational number you can think of, can be described.

describing something means "a finite list of letters that identify this number from any other"

such a finite list of letters can be translated (1 to 1) to a number identifying it.

so that means, "the describable irrational numbers" are countable.

that leaves us with the conclusion that there must be irrational numbers, that cannot be described.

and here's the funny bit, if someone asks "ok, can you give me an example of one?" the answer must be "no. I cannot give you an example of such a number, but I know it exists; and if I could show you one such number, it would instantaneously, and retroactively, cease to be one".

and now to step into philosophy: "can you give me an example of the divine? no, but I am convinced it exists" (well, I am not convinced that it does; but one can make this leap in logic)

A distinction that Newton and others did not get is that Pi equals 3.14... for a circle on an axis, but equals 4 for a rolling circle or an orbit. Calculus and most of physics became a comedy of errors since then.

Just a comment: Although the algebra in the infinite series being applied seems to be "correct", there are issues to consider. 1/1+x = 1 - x + x^2 - x^3 + ... is a valid statement only if -1 < x < 1. In other cases, the series is divergent. Of course, using analytic continuation, one can "assign" values to some divergent series, but such cases need to be stated in precise terms.

the argument is very clever, but I have an objection to a basic point in the video:

where he has the hexagon within the circle within the square,
I accept the circumference of the circle is larger than the hexagon because the shortest distance between 2 points is the straight line joining them,
so the circular arc between 2 points is greater than the segment, add 6 such to get the circle's circumference is greater than the hexagon's.

but with the square containing the circle, although the square's circumference is bigger than the circle's,
I dont think that is self evident. Its true but not self evident.

you need an argument of some form to say that, and I cant off the top of my head think of a straightforward explanation.

The area of the circle is certainly smaller than that of the square, which gives the same conclusion that 4 > pi,
but Veritasium appears to have been arguing circumferences.
Arguing areas, the circle contains the hexagon, so pi > area(hexagon)=6 x 1/2 x base x height = 3 x 1 x squareroot(3)/2=2.598...

Now if you had a square inscribed in a circle, it is certainly true that the circumference of the circle is greater than the square, because the shortest distance between 2 points
is the straight line joining them.

You need to be careful with Newton, he stole a lot of his ideas!

there was a BBC documentary about how Newton stole most of his ideas. In his era, to decide who discovered what first, all communications between scientists had to go via a nexus,
and Newton had spies at the nexus. The clerk at the nexus would forward the idea to Newton, who would announce discovery, and then the clerk would forward the communication to its intended recipient.

They kind of had the scientists over a barrel, because they had to go through the nexus to discover, and Newton was hovering above spearing their inventions!

The documentary said he stole a lot of ideas from Robert Hooke in particular.

Newton was an intellectual pirate.

But Newton could only pull this trick in Britain, and in particular he couldnt steal the invention of calculus which was attributed to Leibniz.

I've, for a LONG time, thought that what was missing from teaching math in schools was a VISUAL way of representing ideas. At around 11:57, you start talking about the idea of the "continuum" of numbers that can exist in Pascal's triangle. You suggest that you can think of each fraction as existing in its own plane in the triangle. The genius that I would like to point out, here, is the visual effect used to demonstrate this that focused (literally focused, as in focusing with a camera) on one plane of fractions at a time, leaving all other planes out of focus to varying degrees. Whoever came up with this visual representation, I would just like to applaud you. Genius. Well done!!

Weird thing about Pi and reality:
As far as modern physics goes, there is no meaning to lengths smaller than the Planck Length. It's not even theoretically possible to measure a smaller length. It's about 10^-35 meters.
On the other end, it is not theoretically possible to observe sizes larger than the observable universe. That's about 10^26.
This means 62 digits of pi are enough to calculate the circumference of the entire observable universe- the largest possible thing- to the precision of the smallest possible measurement.

Digits of pi past the 62nd can never apply to an actual field measurement, not even theoretically. If, for some reason, the actual circumference of circles* differs from calculations at the 63rd digit or beyond, we would never be able to know. Those digits not only have no practical use, according to physics as we know it, they can't.
*Possible in a curved universe!

In reality, there is no such thing as a circle. Only approximations to circles. That's because in the material world, any circle you make or is made, is made up of particles with finite size. They may be extremely small, but are still finite. even when speaking of electromagnetic fields, there are quantum nodes that are distinct entities. Thus all figures that look like circles are really polygons of n sides where n < infinity. That means the ratio of perimeter to radius is not fixed, but varies as n. The fact that pi is an irrational number should have been a clue from the beginning.
Mathematics, in fact, is only a simplified model of reality. There are no infinitely small objects called points, or lines made up of these imaginary objects of zero size, etc. Our math is a very good approximation that of course has been extremely useful to us, but sometimes when we slip into thinking that it is absolutely precise, we can get into difficulties.

I found a way to calculate value of pi with increasing precision. The formula is
Pi = Lim{(n/2).sin(360/n)}
as n -> infinity.
For variety, I have another formula:-
Pi = Lim{n.sin(180/n)}
as n -> infinity.
Both these formulae don't give same results for a specific value of but they give values closer to the Pi given by calculators if you keep increasing the value of n.

Years ago, around 1770, there was a genius named the Vilna Gaon from Vilnius, Lithuania, Jewish expert on the Bible, Jewish Legal scholar, and mystic, who wanted to prove that King Solomon was the most brilliant mind who ever lived. Like any Orthodox Jew he knew that every ancient Hebrew letter had an equally ancient Numerical value.

Aleph is 1
Bet 2
Gimmel 3
Dalet 4
Hey 5 Vav 6 Zayin 7 Het 8
Tet 9 Yud 10 Kaf 20 Lamed 30
Mem 40 Nun 50 Samech 60 Ayin 70 Peh 80 Tzadee 90
Qoof 100 Reish 200 Shin 300
Tav 400.

He noticed the following verse from First Kings chap 7 with regards to building Solomon's Temple: The Bible in the Book of Kings is describing the massive circular copper washing basin where the Priests washed their hands and feet:

וַיַּעַשׂ אֶת-הַיָּם, מוּצָק:  עֶשֶׂר בָּאַמָּה מִשְּׂפָתוֹ עַד-שְׂפָתוֹ עָגֹל סָבִיב, וְחָמֵשׁ בָּאַמָּה קוֹמָתוֹ, וקוה (וְקָו) שְׁלֹשִׁים בָּאַמָּה, יָסֹב אֹתוֹ סָבִיב.23 And he made the molten sea of ten cubits from brim to brim, round in compass, and the height thereof was five cubits; and a line of thirty cubits did compass it round about.
From this we see that the Bible very roughly describes the diameter of this Sea being 10 cubits with a circumference of 30 cubits and therefore with an extremely rough ratio of C/d = 30/10 = 3. He noticed that the word to describe the Circumference was קו (Qoof Vav), but Solomon actually spelled the word with a silent Hey that seems to be an extraneous letter, leading to the full spelling קוה (Qoof Vav Hey).

The great Genius of Vilna then checked out the same account in the Book of 2nd Chronicles chap 4 and saw this: וַיַּעַשׂ אֶת-הַיָּם, מוּצָק:  עֶשֶׂר בָּאַמָּה מִשְּׂפָתוֹ אֶל-שְׂפָתוֹ עָגוֹל סָבִיב, וְחָמֵשׁ בָּאַמָּה קוֹמָתוֹ, וְקָו שְׁלֹשִׁים בָּאַמָּה, יָסֹב אֹתוֹ סָבִיב.2 Also he made the molten sea of ten cubits from brim to brim, round in compass, and the height thereof was five cubits; and a line of thirty cubits did compass it round about.

The exact same verse where the word Qav is spelled WITHOUT the silent Hey! Quickly the Gaon calculated that the word Qav with the silent Hey in First Kings had the numerical value of 100+ 6+ 5 =111 and that the numerical value of Qav without the Hey in 2nd Chronicles was 100+6= 106.

He then took the ratio 111/ 106 and multiplied it by 3 =
3 x 111÷106 = 3.141509434.

So the Wise King Solomon in the 10th Century bce may have been a bit wiser than the much later Archimedes!

I see a problem...If we use a method for calculating PI that is an approximation, then the resulting calculation will always be wrong. Example: If we create a series of polygons, say 2^100, it will NEVER be correct because there will always errors in the Arc Length. So to say that PI is an infinite series, is only true because we are using the wrong technique. The problem with Newton's method is that it uses Cube Root of 3 which does not exist. So the method is still not correct because it is using techniques that are wrong. So how can we calculate the value of PI using techniques that are NOT approximation techniques. Any time we use an approximation to calculate anything, the resulting answer will also be an approximation.

I don't know if anyone noticed, but at 14:10 he said "Increase each power of x by 1, and divide by the new power" and the numbers in the animation are wrong.

The x-es (plural for many x lol) shown are:
x^2, x^4, x^6, and x^8

So as per definition, it should become:

The April 1998 issue of the
newsletter contained an article claiming that the Alabama state
legislature had voted to change the value of the mathematical constant
pi from 3.14159 to the 'Biblical value' of 3.0. Before long the article
had made its way onto the internet, and then it rapidly made its way
around the world, forwarded by people in their email. It only became
apparent how far the article had spread when the Alabama legislature
began receiving hundreds of calls from people protesting the
legislation. The original article, which was intended as a parody of
legislative attempts to circumscribe the teaching of evolution, was
written by physicist Mark Boslough.

खलजीवितखाताव गलहाला रसंधरः ||

      This is the pronunciation in English:
Gopeebhaagya Madhuvraathah Shrugashodhadhi Samdhigah
 Khalajeevithakhaathaava Galahaalaa Rasamdharah

       This is the translation, based on it's code. This code is based off of the main Sanskrit letters in the Sloka:
ga-3, pa-1, bha-4, ya 1, ma-5, Dhu-9, ra-2, tha-6, shru-5, ga-3, sho-5, dha-8, Dhi -9, sa-7, Dha 9, ga-3, kha-2, la-3, jee-8, vi-4, tha-6, kha-2, tha-6, va-4, ga-3, la-3, ha-8, la-3, ra-2, sa-7, Dha-9, ra-2

      This is the actual value of Pi:
3.1415926535897932384626433832792…

      The researchers actually have found out that this very Sloka has three meanings. The first meaning of this Sloka is in favor of Lord Shiva. The second meaning of this Sloka is in favor of Lord Krishna. The third meaning of this Sloka is the value of Pi up to 32 decimals.

The reason why there is a shift in buildings in New York is because of the height of the bedrock. The buildings are taller wherever the bedrock is higher and vice versa. All the brilliant ppl who have stepped humanity forward by a great leap have been ppl who MADE CONNECTIONS between data that we already knew about but couldn't see the connections between yet.
For example, when Einstein formulated his special relativity theory, we already knew about time, space and gravity, but he was the one to see the connections between them! And when he had finished with his brain, they dissected it and found that the only thing that was special about it, was the exceptional number of cxonnections BETWEEN all the neurons... we were literally seeing how his brain worked!!!
Same thing with Newton... mathematical concepts we were already aware of, yet he was the one to see the connections between them.
So by extension, we should be focusing ourselves upon seeing new connections between the things we already know, and we certainly have plenty of knowledge and data about alot of things now, so when we look at the world now, if we want to break open new unexplored frontiers, we should be looking for the connections between it all... 😉

14:35 "A not good math paper has zero ideas, it's just pushing through things that everybody already knows but nobody bothered to do."

I take issue with this statement a smidge. If it hasn't been tested or proven then it is still a good paper. In the same vein that people should publish a paper when their experiment or hypothesis fails. Knowing what doesn't work is just as good as knowing what does. In fact isn't that what Newton did? Everyone "already knew" that the binomial theorem only works for positive integers so what else is there to do? It was Newton pushing through that mindset that nobody bothered to consider.

Regardless of that nitpick, I think the original intent was more hyping up Newton and how brilliant he was. But we shouldn't malign others in the process from a subjective point of view.

New idea #5 introduces √3/8 in the calculation, i.e. an irrational number, which is what the expansion and integration allowed Newton to avoid up until new idea #4. The presence of an irrational number in the calculation is not diminishing the returns of having a faster converging series in new idea #5, compared to new idea #4, given the expansion for √3 that he worked out too (as shown at 12:33 in the video) and allowed him to calculate it to an arbitrary precision first.

Just one correction.
Newton's method is no more used to calculate pi. Around 1910 an Indian Mathematician, Srinivasa Ramanujan found several rapidly converging infinite series of π, which can compute 8 decimal places of π with each term in the series. Since the 1980s, his series have become the basis for the fastest algorithms currently used by Yasumasa Kanada and the Chudnovsky brothers to compute π.
Nowadays more improved versions of Ramanujan's work are used to calculate pi to very very high accuracy.

Knowing a decimal approximation to pi to 10 thousand decimal places is a glorious waste of time. Indeed, the value of pi is already known exactly: it is the ratio of a round circle's circumference to its diameter. Every round circle has the same ratio. So every round circle allows you to calculate pi exactly. What could be simpler or more beautiful than that? There is literally no point in trying to make such a ridiculous decimal conversion. Such an effort is, in a very literal sense, an attempt to fit a round peg in a square hole.

There is no such thing as a perfect (i.e., actual) circle…all physical reality is discrete rather than continuous. Therefore, all ‘perfect’ circles are fantasies (which is fine, if clearly described as such). All physical ‘circles’ are actually high frequency polygons. Without exception. (Only the frequency of a given physical ‘circle’ is exceptional/unique).

Moreover, there is not such thing as a perfect VIRTUAL circle, i.e. the ‘trace’ of a hypothetical 'perfectly circular path', in as much as all pathways/orbits require time and space. That is, given the necessity of time and space, all circular paths (including paths-as-orbits, and even potentially ‘perfectly circular’ paths) are spiral-linear, of necessity.

That is: The beginning and end point of any virtually circular path never coincide—are never unified—as a function of time and space (and the necessary differences implied thereto)…thus, the necessary result is a spiral (no matter how ‘flat’, no matter how close to true ‘circularity’, the spiral may or may not be).

Thus is the irrationality of pi as a so-called ‘circular’ measurement a function of a 'circular fantasy', rather than an actual circle, which, per the above, does not and cannot exist.

Which in no way implies that the powerful estimating nature of pi should be eliminated...rather, given a commitment to a broader perspective, so would we communicate pi's specific and true nature.

Mādhava of Sangamagrāma (c. 1340 – c. 1425) discovered infinite series for expansions of the trigonometric sine, cosine and arctangent functions, and the special case of the power series expansion of the arctangent function yielding a formula for computing π. It's the Fosbury Flop of pi.  Until the 1968 Olympics, high jumpers literally just straight Mario-jumped over the pole.  When Dick Fosbury used the backwards arch (which passed his CoG under the pole while his body curved over it), the high jump was forever changed.  The difference being, of course, that Fosbury did not straight-up invent the flop on his own, like Newton did.  Instead, he refined techniques that were promising, but had yet to really pan out.  In this comparison, Newton did everything but invent the high jump event itself.

For myself such mathematics was seen as drudgery. BUT I then trained as a land surveyor where such mathematical tools were required and I started to understand so much more. Translating pure mathematics into practical solutions was what I needed to gain a healthy understanding.

In Geodesy (manipulating mathematical representations to approximate the shape of the earth) you need to find practical solutions to compute results to an accuracy required. The use of calculus and infinite series were the tools required to do so. And interestingly I learned that part of the practical methodology (linked to what I term 'measurement science') was using these mathematical tools to confirm when you had a result to an accuracy required.

Regarding calculating the sqrt(3): there is a better method (which I assume was known before Newton, but rarely discussed now) which does not involve infinite sum, but instead involves simple arithmetic operation, similar to division.  Each iteration in the square root process gives one (EXACT) decimal place in the result, so getting sqrt(3) to 6 places would involve only 6 iterations, and knowing that every one of those digits is CORRECT.  Determining the "error" in calculating finite subset of infinite sums always is a challenge, often involving many higher levels of math theory.

What this treatment of the subject leaves out is the deeper reason WHY our entire geometric system NEEDS pi in order to do certain basic calculations of very common objects.  The speakers simply ASSUME that the geometric system should primarily be based on shapes which are designed by means of straight lines.  It is clear, if you base your geometric system on shapes which are defined by straight lines, you will need to use SOME special function or functions in order to calculate things like the circumference and area of any shapes which are NOT defined by STRAIGHT LINES.  The real question to ask is: why based a geometric system on objects defined by straight lines?   The question really should be asked because straight lines do not exist, or, at the very least, are very rare.  Look around in nature, almost nothing consists of pure straight lines.  Living things are all composed of curved shapes of various kinds.  And even inanimate objects tend to be made up of rough surfaces.  Finding  something like a natural stone which which is perfectly smooth is rare; fashioning an object which has a strictly straight line, like a sharp knife, is very challenging---perhaps impossible if you are able to view these things with a microscope.  That is to say, within the realm of human perception, straight lines are not at all predominant.  Actually, CURVES are much more common than straight lines.  Moreover, if you go beyond human perception and talk on the level of physics---well, cosmologists will tell you that space, itself, is curved.  If space itself is curved, then whatever exists within space must, inherently, be a part of that curvature.  In other words, in the most fundamental sense, absolute straight lines do not exist.  The closest any line comes to being straight is a relatively straightness within the context of universal curvature of the space within with the line exists.  Given the fact that straight lines are so hard to find with human perception and do not exist at all at the level of basic physics, WHY would we have a geometric system which is BASED ON STRAIGHT LINES?  Why don't we have a geometric system in which curves are the NORM?  If we did, then we would use a sort of alternative pi for adjusting that geometric system to calculating the diameter and area of objects which are defined by non-existent straight lines.  The advantage would be that our geometric system would correspond to REALITY.  The question which nobody ever wants to discuss is why mankind adopted a geometric system which does NOT correspond to reality (one based on nonexistent straight lines) instead of a geometric system which WOULD correspond to reality (one based on objects defined by curved lines).  If you do not address this question, then you're really just engaging in propaganda for a geometric system which, ultimately, must reflect political motivations.  Why political?  Well, it is obviously not SCiENTIFIC to base a geometric system on something which does not exist (straight lines).  So there must be some non-scientific reason for using such a geometric system.  Whatever that non-scientific reason is, or reasons are, it or they must be, in some sense, political, reflecting policy choices or attitudes or preferences rather than the search for truth.

The proof at 1:35 would be much more convincing if expressed in terms of areas. How can you be sure that the perimeter of the inscribed hexagon (circumscribed square) is lesser (greater) than that of the circle? Sure, we can eyeball and it seems pretty clear. But it's not always true that an inscribed shape has a smaller perimeter and a circumscribed shape has greater perimeter. (e.g., imagine a really squiggly inscribed shape.) More work is needed to make the proof rigorous. However, the area of an inscribed shape is always lesser, and the area of the circumscribed shape is always greater.

There are 2 spaceships called S & S'
u = the speed between them
S' overtakes S
They see a flash of light in the distance
Then for reasons i'm a bit hazy on we get:
t = x/c
t' = x'/c
x = γ(x' + ut')
x' = γ(x - ut)
They are getting different values for c but experiments show c is constant so they assign an error factor called γ

Multiply the 2 x terms together
xx' = γ²(x' + ut')(x - ut)
= γ²(xx' + ut'x - x'ut - u²tt')
=> xx' = γ²(xx' + uxx'/c - ux'x/c - u²xx'/c²) looks bad but it simplifies
=> xx' = γ²(xx' - u²xx'/c²)
Divide by xx'
=> 1 = γ²(1 - u²/c²)
_______
=> γ = √ 1 - ̲ ̲u ̲²̲
c²

0 < integral x^8(1-x)^8*(25+816*x^2)/(3164*(1+x^2)) from x= 0 to 1 = 355/113 - pi, So 355/133 > pi and 355/133 is closer to pi than 22/7 is :-).

In fact, if you replace 3164(1+x^2) with 3164(1+0^2) and again by 3164(1+1^2) and integrate between x= 0 to 1 and compare these results to the integral above, then we find that 3.14159274 > pi > 3.14159257. Note: pi = 3.141593 ( 6 decimal places).

No needed to calculate hundreds of terms in a series to compute Pi to six decimal places.

The polynomials are linear approximations form Pascal's triangle where each member is linearly increased.
Circle is not a linear shape. π (or d = 2π, diameter) is defined as a ratio... I repeat - A RATIO - between the Circumference and the Diameter of any Circle.

Thus, and since we do not have a ratio from Pascal's triangle, the result can only be a linear approximation. Very similar (quite the same) as the linear regular polygons Archimedes used to approximate the circular shape.
In Calculus we also use such approximations.

The natural value of π = 4 : √φ ≈ 3.14460...

So at some point, I thought "even numbers, math and so science" are not true.
Numbers are a concept created by humans. At the moment, in my opinion (you are free to help me change my mind), science is just a series of rules that "happen" to describe, until a certain degree of precision, "natural" phenomena we experience in our lives.

So, for example, I could say that the "law of gravity" does not exist as we imagine it and I would probably be right, I mean it works (here, but are we sure it is always the same everywhere?), but it does not exist certainly as we called it and as we defined it, because again we defined it through numbers and math which is a human invention (a system of rules that tries to be consistent).

Is it correct or not? Are numbers an objective truth or not? Are numbers a natural entity that exists outside human perception? I doubt it (for example different kinds of numeric systems exist).

I'd like you to try to talk about these points.

The problem with Newton and most of the math today is that is relies on Classical Physics. We live in a quantum world. They also rely on induction, which states that the same pattern should continue to infinity. So the terms in the expansion go on forever and it is assumed that they can go on forever. No on has tested this and you can't test this. Then bring in quantum physics and it is a game changer. You can't have a "point" you have the uncertainty principal. So as you are writing down your infinitely long expansion of PI, eventually the uncertainty principle will come into play and the numbers will get fuzzy. No math today takes these things into account. Godel , Turing, all rely on induction and classical physics to construct their theories of math. Classical physics does not exist , it is fake, so how can you base math on a fake concept ???
Take the concept of a circle. What is a circle.? A curved line drawn equidistant from a central point. So how do you do this ? With a pencil ? You have to use some physical tools in the real quantum world to draw the circle. The central point is going to move around. How do you deal with that? That is one problem , just for starters. How do you guarantee the distance from the center to the circle is constant, while you are drawing the circle ? A string will stretch. You would be better to use light and time it's round trip. Then the uncertainty principle will affect the clock a little bit and you will never have a constant distance from the center.
I really don't know how to approach this problem but it seems like no one else is working on these problems.

Sort of a dumb question here -- my apologies in advance...

We know that Pi is an essential key in a number of mathematical applications used today. But, as I've always understood it, at it's most simple definition, it's the relationship between the diameter and the circumference of a "perfect" circle...

So, my question:
The lengths to which early mathematicians went to calculate a more precise -- yet ultimately imperfect -- value for Pi...

Was this a matter of actual utility?
Or just academic curiousity?
Simply "one-upmanship"...?
Or did they have some practical purpose in mind?

A big chunk of what is being studied today by youngsters comes from Newton. He spent his whole life trying to understand how to define the ratio between the circumference of the circle and it's diameter. But it goes beyond that... it's actually about the UNIVERSE.

He was able to do that because many other mathematicians before him spent their whole life building bits and pieces over the knowledge they had at the time.

But it goes beyond the lifetime of many fellow humans and circles and ratios... it's about the world we live in, and how a small part of the universe works. It's about understanding more about how the world around us works, and this is the universal language of the universe.

A circle does not really exist. It's a trick of the mind. You simply cannot have a geometrical structure where every point is equally distant from the center.
A circle is just a polygon with a great (but not infinite) number of faces, depending of the precision of the measurement, regardless of its size.
This is the reason why the value of pi has never been resolved and will not. It's simply a fraction that can't be determined.

Fun fact, the 2nd highest dimensional measure of a circle/sphere/hypersphere will always be the derivative of the highest dimensional measure. So what's the derivative of pi*r^2 with respect to r? 2*pi*r. What's the derivative of 4/3 * pi * r^3? 4*pi*r^2.  Now why is the circumference of a circle the derivative of the area, and the surface area of a sphere the derivative of its volume? Because if you increase the diameter of a sphere just a tiny bit, it INCREASES its VOLUME by a differential of size equal to the surface area. And the same is true of any higher dimensional hypersphere for the same reason.

Important thing to note here is that infinite series don't behave very nicely in general. For example, it is true to say 1/(1 + x) = 1 - x + x^2 - x^3 + ... but ONLY for -1 < x < 1. This reasoning is exactly why in the video when computing sqrt(3) they first had to rewrite it as 2sqrt(1 - 1/4).

Building on this, we must be careful when computing integrals over infinite series as the integral of a seemingly nice infinite series need not be "nice" in the sense that you get a finite number. See the historic example of Gabriel's Horn for a good example.

Just a bit of context here: Archimedes wouldn’t have considered pi to be a number. Instead, he was just calculating the ratio of the circumference of a circle to it’s diameter. But, ratios were not considered numbers at the time, and the numerical value we know didn’t actually show up for a long time. He would have left his approximation as the ratio of two integers.

At this time when calculus was just being invented by Newton and Leibniz, the concept of series convergence was totally unknown. It will take another hundred years for a mathematically rigorous treatment of the subject, beginning with the introduction of the limit. We can say that Newton was mathematically lucky that the binomial series he was using converges. Today we know that this series converges absolutely if |x| < 1, or -1 < x < 1. From the eyes of modern mathematics, we can see that is indeed the case because of where x lies in relation to the unit circle.

I love this video! Very clearly explained. Props on the pronunciation of Ceulen :) One hopefully helpful criticism: The typeface you are using now has some letter and number shapes that are easy to be confused or hard to discern in small sizes and low resolution. In typographers’ terms, it is too geometric and its counters are too closed. That means, for example, that the letter O is too close in shape to the number 0, the letter e becomes a blob, and the numbers 3 and 8 are easy to confuse. It does have some numbers whose shapes are already an improvement, such as 6 and 1. I recommend looking at the the differences on the spectrum from Avant Garde (a “geometric sans serif”, similar to the typeface used here) to Futura, Helvetica, Frutiger (a “humanist sans serif”) and finally a “Modern Dutch” typeface such as DTL Argo.

0:55 Lol, imagine saying "length is 1/2 circumference" and then saying "so that's pi * r" instead of the much clearer "1/2 tau * r." The reason 1/2 * (tau * r) * r is much better than pi * r * r is right in this very example. Triangles. We derive the area of a circle from triangles whose area is 1/2 * base * height, where for a circle the base is tau * r and the hight is r, so 1/2*tau*r^2. Pi is a cruel joke.

Very interesting. But I lost track completely when calculus popped up! Which brings me to a rather painful personal discovery... I was good at maths, so good in fact that I took my O Level maths (old UK exam usually taken at 15 - now called. GCSE) a year early and got a good pass. But then along comes A Level maths and bloody calculus - and I discover that I simply can't do it!!  Which (to me) indicates that (unless I have a uniquely weird brain) calculus is some sort of step up in maths - in simple terms, it is not normal maths. My clever normal maths brain just couldn't handle it. And I'm left wondering if this is just the only step change in maths - from simple maths to conceptual maths? Or does something similar happen throughout the whole of maths?  Are there people reading this who could understand calculus easily, but then found maths at some higher level incomprehensible?  Or is maths just maths, and some of it is just harder??  (For those in the US, just ignore the 'unnecessary' 's' on 'math'!)

Newton did NOT invent calculus. Both differentiation and integration were around for over a hundred years before Newton. The fundamental theorem of calculus was proven by Isaac Barrow, Newton's teacher, while Newton was still a student. Newton made many contributions to calculus, but he did not invent the field.

Incidentally, the debate between Newton and Leibniz was about who invented the method for using infinitesimals to reason about derivatives. Newton called infinitesimals "Fluxions". It was not the foundation of the field, but a new, and powerful, reasoning method for it. Since we teach limits now instead of infinitesimals (though, they're still used in Synthetic Differential Geometry and some other fields) the debate seems a bit foreign to the modern calculus student, but simplifying it to who "invented calculus" is ahistorical.

With Aryabhatta (476 AD), a new era of mathematics dawned in India. Aryabhatta approximated Π = 62832/20000 = 3.1416. This was astonishingly correct to 4 decimal places (better than 22/7, which is correct only to 2 places). The Indian values of Π (√10, 62832/20000) were later included in Chinese and Arabs literature.

Many years later, another great mathematician of the Aryabhatta School of mathematics, named Madhava (1340 AD). Madhava gave the value of Π to be 2827,4333,8823,3 / 9*1011. This approximation yields correct value of Π to 11 decimal places. This value of Π is still in use in modern mathematics. Madhava also knew the Madhava series of Π/4, which was rediscovered in Europe by Leibniz in 1673.

The real revelation for me was that a line perpendicular to the halfway point of a circle's radius will exactly intersect the edge at the 30 degree mark. Given how much about circles involves irrational numbers, I was not expecting something that clean. And I bet it's played a huge role in simplifying calculations involving circles over the years (and might even account for why we use degrees instead of, say, powers of two or ten like we do for virtually everything else). Given that, I could swear I was never taught it in geometry class.

EDIT: Actually wait. I just remembered that If you draw a circle, then draw another circle whose center is anywhere on the first circle's edge, then draw a third circle starting from one of the points where those two intersect, the three intersection points form a perfect equilateral (120-degree) triangle. They even showed that on Sesame Street. So yeah, the relationship between right angles and 30-degree segments of circles is obvious.

Great video I really enjoyed the exploration of how Newton calculated pi; however, you stated that the polygon method was the only way people calculated pi for 2000 years til Newton. This is actually wrong, there are at least 2 Indian Mathematises that figured out how to calculate pi without using the polygon method. Nilakantha Somayaji and Madhava of Sangamagramma both discovered the Maclaurin expansion of arctan(x) and used the special case x=1 to find pi/4 = 1 -1/3 +1/5 -1/7... Furthermore we know that Madhava used a 21 terms of this series to gain an 11 decimal place approximation for pi. Both of these mathematicians did their work well over 100 years before Newton was born. I very much enjoyed the video but I wanted to offer the correction as it is very common that non-European and non-white mathematicians are left out of discussions of math's history.

The argument using perimeter to show that pi must be between 3 and 4 is a bit shaky because it's a bit unclear where you get the inequalities from. If we're talking about general shapes in the plane, it's entirely possible for one shape to lie entirely inside another and yet have a much larger perimeter (think about a spiky star or other wiggly shape lying inside the circle). The case of the hexagon inside the circle is a bit clearer, if we understand that line segments are the shortest curves between two points, then you can divide the figure into 6 parts where the circle and hexagon meet each other, and it's clear that each edge of the hexagon would then have to be no longer than the circular arc because it's a line segment. For the square comparison, it's less obvious, since you're comparing circular arcs with pairs of line segments in each quadrant. It's intuitive that the circle is shorter here, but actually reasoning it out is hard.

In order to help understand why it's tricky, for any epsilon > 0 (no matter how small), it's possible to replace the circle with a curve that never gets more than a distance epsilon away from the circle, and which has arbitrarily long perimeter, by just adding lots of tiny wiggles or spikes.

One thing we might use to shore up the argument is to use the fact that these shapes are all convex, but the fact that when one convex shape lies inside another, it must have smaller perimeter, even if true, isn't a super simple thing to prove either (if you're going to try, start with only polygons at first before worrying about more general curves).

If you're starting from first principles, using area is a much easier way to get inequalities.

14:35 Why is not introducing new ideas a not-good-math-paper?! Most subjects in math have dozens of ways to introduce them and to think about them (e.g. you can define tangent vectors as derivatives of curves or as linear forms on germs; or you can think about logic as symbol manipulation with rules or as games on graphs; there are more than 35 ways to think about the derivative of a function). I had a very hard time understanding differential forms, because all definitions of them are so obscure. But then I found a paper that didn't define them as sections of the space of alternating multilinear maps on the tangent bundle of a manifold, but as functions mapping parallelotopes to their measure, and suddenly integration in differential geometry made sense to me. Even though this paper pushed no new ideas in the world of mathematics, it was a great paper, because it gave me a new point of view on a subject that I was struggling with.

14th century Indian mathematician Madhava used Leibniz series (Madhava series?) to obtain Pi to 11 decimals, and either him or one of his predecessors calculated pi to 17 decimals. The painfully slow convergence of the Leibniz series was improved upon by the calculation of an error term to correct the end result..!

Just thought this was worth a mention. Indian mathematicians had the <sic> Hindu-Arabic numeral system for longer than western mathematicians, and so were able to come up with novel ways to solve problems much sooner. Just goes to show how the thirst for knowledge is our universal glue.

Take the great pyramid of Giza.   The ratio of the perimeter to the height is Pi (to a 10,000th precision). The ratio of the hypotenuse of the flat face to the height is "chi", the golden ratio.   In modern calculations, they diverge in accuracy after the 5th decimal place.  But in engineering terms, even at that scale,  that is spot on.  We know that mathematically the relationship is false.  But 7,000 (or more) years ago, At a level of accuracy to 1/10,000 this was a physical certainty that these numbers were related.   I only wish it were also true mathematically.

Why didn't they just make a protractor (string, pin, pencil), draw a circle on a nicely sanded plank of wood with known thickness, cut out that circle, wax it to make it not absorb any water, and then immerse the (very flat) cylinder in water?
Or instead of wood, just make it out of clay and make a ceramic cylinder. Immerse that. Could also do stone if you want.
The displaced volume, divided by the thickness, is the area of the circle. Divide that by the known circle dimensions (measurable) and you have an experimentally verified approximation for Pi.
Do this with a bunch of various disks & cylinders and average it out to get more precision. At least good enough for the purpose of construction, logistics and so forth.
This method would work with neolithic technology and very simple arithmetic. They could have done this ages and ages ago.

Trying to help others: We can see that one side of the rectangle must be half of the total crust, which means half the circumference. Since the circumference is π * diameter (as shown at 0:35), which if the same as π * 2 * radius, then half of the circumference is (π * 2 * radius) / 2, which is π * radius.

1:05 if you missed where the πr came from:
The circumference is π times the diameter (d), so πd. But the diameter is simply twice the radius. Hence: 2πr.
Since we are using half the circumference: 2πr/2 = πr. And that's where it came from.

You can determine pi, using a scale. From a uniform material make a square with sides equal 2r. Now make a circle of radius r. Weigh each.
